item.title: Coronavirus: Lockdown easing on hold as shielding ends
item.description: More than two million vulnerable people can now leave their home for the first time since lockdown began.

item.title: News Corp: Rupert Murdoch's son James quits company
item.description: He resigns from the influential media company's board, citing "disagreements over editorial content".

item.title: Coronavirus: More than half of furloughed staff 'back at work'
item.description: A think tank suggests 4.5 million are currently furloughed as employers begin contributions today.

item.title: Bafta TV Awards 2020: Ten things we learned at the virtual ceremony
item.description: The night's big highlights, from DIY trophies to Kermit and Miss Piggy.

item.title: Coronavirus: Saturday update as shielding ends for millions of people
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus outbreak today.

item.title: Coronavirus: Locals in Cornwall 'too scared' to go shopping
item.description: Some Cornish residents say the crowds are "madness" and they are banning their children from towns.

item.title: Twitter hack: Bognor Regis man one of three charged
item.description: A UK man and two people in Florida have been charged over the hijacking of US Twitter accounts.

item.title: Trump says he will ban TikTok in the US
item.description: US security officials fear the Chinese-owned app could be used to collect Americans' personal data.

item.title: Leicester Muslims mark second Eid of extended lockdown
item.description: Leicester's religious leaders and council urge people to pray and celebrate the festival at home.

item.title: British Airways pilots vote to accept jobs deal
item.description: The agreement means the airline will cut pay by 20% temporarily and make about 270 redundancies.

item.title: Hong Kong 'seeking arrest' of fleeing activists
item.description: Six activists, including some now in the UK, are reportedly wanted under the new security law.

item.title: Dangerous heat wave forecast for south-western areas of US
item.description: Forecasters say temperatures could rise to 50C on Saturday in parts of Utah, Nevada and California.

item.title: Whaley Bridge dam crisis: What's changed a year on?
item.description: Residents in Whaley Bridge reflect on last year's dam crisis that threatened to wipe out their town.

item.title: The Papers: 'PM slams brakes' amid 'second wave risk'
item.description: Boris Johnson's announcement that rules will not be relaxed for at least a fortnight dominates Saturday's papers.

item.title: Coronavirus: Tracking new outbreaks in the sewers
item.description: Around 15,000 new cases of the disease have been reported in Spain in the past week.

item.title: India Atkinson: TikTok disability educator goes viral
item.description: India Atkinson's videos address misconceptions about a condition that left her without fingers on one hand.

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how long should I self-isolate?
item.description: The BBC’s Laura Foster explains how you can recognise the symptoms of coronavirus.

item.title: Week in pictures: 25 July-31 July 2020
item.description: A selection of powerful news photographs taken around the world this week.

item.title: MOT rules in lockdown: How to get your car out of lockdown
item.description: Haven't used your car in a while? Here are five tips to help you get going again.

item.title: Croke Park: Muslims celebrate Eid in the home of Irish sport
item.description: Islamic leader says event sends a message "to the whole world" that Ireland is a welcoming country.

item.title: Job-hunting: 'I apply everywhere - few firms reply'
item.description: The pandemic has created a desperate hunt for jobs in an increasingly competitive market.

item.title: Coronavirus: The bogus meme targeting Dr Fauci, and other fake claims
item.description: A round-up of false and misleading claims circulating on American social media this week.

item.title: US election 2020: The war hero who could be Biden's running mate
item.description: Senator Tammy Duckworth is an Iraq war veteran and the first Thai-American woman elected to Congress.

item.title: James Baldwin: World's fastest gamer to real life racer
item.description: Gaming gives the 22-year-old a second chance of achieving his real life racing dreams.

item.title: Black Lives Matter: 'Backlash has been divisive like Brexit'
item.description: People have been "shocked", "upset" and "drained" by friends' reactions to Black Lives Matter.

item.title: In Pictures: Alan Parker's film legacy
item.description: A look at some of the most memorable moments from the late director's filmography.

item.title: Arsenal want to 'save season' by winning FA Cup - Lacazette
item.description: Arsenal's Alexandre Lacazette says the players are excited about the FA Cup final because they know they can "save our season".

item.title: 'We must put ourselves under FA Cup final pressure' - Lampard
item.description: Chelsea manager Frank Lampard says his side "cannot cruise" into Saturday's FA Cup final against Arsenal at Wembley.

item.title: 12 teams, 12 questions for a new Scottish Premiership season
item.description: As the Scottish Premiership resumes, Tom English poses a question for each of the 12 top-flight teams.

item.title: Albon crashes heavily as Stroll goes fastest in British Grand Prix practice
item.description: Alexander Albon suffers a heavy crash in his Red Bull as Lance Stroll's Racing Point set the pace in second practice at the British Grand Prix.

item.title: Who is Ferran Torres? The inside story of Man City's imminent new signing
item.description: With Valencia's Ferran Torres set to join Manchester City, Guillem Balague talks to the 20-year-old to get his inside story.

item.title: Trump advances at World Championship after first-round scare
item.description: Defending world champion Judd Trump survives a first-round scare to edge past Tom Ford at the Crucible Theatre in Sheffield.

item.title: London 2012: Anthony Joshua, Andy Murray and Bradley Wiggins in best of day five action
item.description: Catch up with the best of the action from day five of London 2012 as Great Britain's Helen Glover and Heather Stanning win Great Britain's first gold of the Games and Bradley Wiggins rides to glory.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of more restrictions?

item.title: Coronavirus: Do people still have to shield?
item.description: As restrictions lift, you might feel anxious about how to stay safe. Here's what experts advise.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does my boss have to do to keep me safe?
item.description: Employers in England can now ask people to return to the workplace, but what precautions must they take?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: Many weddings were cancelled during lockdown, while some will have to change to meet the new rules.

item.title: Coronavirus: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Museums, galleries and cinemas are added to the places where face coverings sgould be worn in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the new lockdown rules for Greater Manchester?
item.description: More than four million people in northern England face new restrictions, but what does a local lockdown mean?

item.title: Coronavirus: Can my granddaughters still visit? And other local lockdown questions
item.description: Local lockdowns are in force in England, but what are the rules? We answer some of your questions.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can I get facial treatment at a beauty salon?
item.description: As some lockdown easing is delayed in England, how are customers being kept safe?

item.title: Quiz: Can you answer these six basic questions about coronavirus in the UK?
item.description: Take this quiz to test your knowledge about coronavirus and the rules and advice about it in the UK

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: What happens when the furlough scheme ends?
item.description: Nine million people have accessed the scheme, which now allows furloughed workers to come back part-time.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Coronavirus: Am I eligible for a test?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Social distancing and lockdown rules are changing in England - but what can you now do?

item.title: Coronavirus: How many more people are dying?
item.description: Why looking at 'excess deaths' reveals Covid-19's true death toll.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's happening to free school meals this summer?
item.description: The government in England will now provide free school meals vouchers over the summer holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: Why isn't the UK testing travellers on arrival?
item.description: Some countries offer a choice - get tested or go into quarantine. Should the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where can I go on holiday? A guide to destinations
item.description: As people in the UK get the green light to go abroad again, here's a look at what's in store for travellers.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus: How can I use the 'eat out to help out scheme'?
item.description: Thousands of venues will take part in a discounting scheme to help boost the hospitality industry.

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: How close are we and who will get it?
item.description: The BBC looks at the work needed to create a coronavirus vaccine and when one might be ready.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK's travel rules and which countries can you visit?
item.description: New agreements mean people entering the UK from certain countries will not have to quarantine.

item.title: Coronavirus: When I come back from Spain, will I get paid if I self-isolate?
item.description: The 14-day quarantine on travellers arriving from Spain has caused "uncertainty and confusion".

item.title: Step-by-step guide to making your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Coronavirus lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but who is responsible for enforcing them?

item.title: Coronavirus: False and misleading claims about vaccines debunked
item.description: Misinformation about coronavirus vaccine trials has been spreading on social media.

item.title: Working from home: How to cut your tax bill
item.description: Home workers can claim tax allowances for their lighting, heating and other expenses.

item.title: Racism and statues: How the toxic legacy of empire still affects us
item.description: BBC News presenter Clive Myrie says racism was the rocket fuel that fuelled British conquest of much of the planet - and its effects are still felt today.

item.title: Churchill's legacy leaves Indians questioning his hero status
item.description: Yogita Limaye explores how Indians are questioning more about the dark chapters of colonial history.

item.title: Aboriginal Australians 'still suffering effects of colonial past'
item.description: The BBC's Shaimaa Khalil explores how the life chances of indigenous Australians are rooted in colonialism.

item.title: Legacy of Kenyan clan 'branded evil' by colonialists
item.description: The BBC’s Anne Soy travelled to her birthplace to meet clan members in her Kalenjin ethnic community.

item.title: Fergal Keane: My family and the empire's complex legacy
item.description: The BBC's Fergal Keane looks at Ireland's colonial past and the allegiances his relatives had within it.
